The 3 pillars of a self sustaining MakerDAO: 

Elected Paid Contributors: experts hired directly by the protocol

Maker Improvement Proposals: formalized processes for decisions and operations

Vote Delegates: an ecosystem of "protocol politicians" that makes MKR voting easier

At the Maker Governance Meeting that's beginning one hour from now, I will be presenting the Foundations vision for a Self-Sustaining MakerDAO to the maker core community. But first I have a podcast with @CamiRusso. Exciting times!

@kaiynne @teo_leibowitz IMO 3.12 proved why it isn't sustainable or scalable to rely only on a single correlated asset. BTW I was an uber decentralization maximalist 5 years ago. I truly expected and hoped Dai would be a completely government/custodian free asset. But then reality sets in
RT @CamiRusso: üéôÔ∏èInterviewing @RuneKek from @MakerDAO in about an hour. What do you want me to ask?

@kaiynne @teo_leibowitz Decentralization is a subjective and ideological concept (risk management is what actually matters). But IMO thousands of assets and custodians transparently diversified across 100+ jurisdictions, backstopped and governed by MKR, is safe and financially scalable decentralization.

@kaiynne @teo_leibowitz Yes, it is important to practice risk management and diversify across jurisdictions - that's why there are MKR holders. \nAgain, it also applies to how crypto markets are structured - almost 100% of BTC and ETH demand side is under the jurisdiction of either China or US.

@kaiynne @teo_leibowitz I agree that it is not a problem because of diversification of risk. Which is exactly why diversification of the Maker collateral portfolio with assets of different risk profiles is so important.
@kaiynne @teo_leibowitz By this logic, how is ETH not already subject to the whims of Coinbase, Binance, Bitfinex and the other mega exchanges that control all the liquidity?

@Prometheus_DLT @BtcBombo @udiWertheimer That's a shame, but of course there is no way to avoid this issue. I don't think bonding is a silver bullet because the users end up bearing the cost of the capital inefficiency, and at that point it becomes harder to compete with a diversified set of high quality multisigs
@BtcBombo @udiWertheimer So how can it be attacked and what other risks does it have?

@udiWertheimer BTC in DeFi will always require multisigs in some way - but at maturity the solution would be utilizing a diversified set of highly secure multisigs. So like spreading your risk across bitmex, coinbase, kraken, bitfinex in a unified UX and no KYC.
@udiWertheimer Perhaps this is a good time to shill BTC vaults are coming: https://t.co/qFXrXnAqtI - Hopefully with better security/decentralization than bitmex.

@udiWertheimer Respect that you actually recognized the acronym! Hopefully it will pass on Friday - now that the MCD codebase has been live for a while, and the dark fix technology exists, the GSM should have minimal impact on technical risk.
@udiWertheimer Maker: *Activates GSM*\n\nFudi:

@koeppelmann I get it, I'm lamenting the fact that users only consider the type of risk that's the latest fad. In 2016 that was technical risk. Now it's cryptoeconomic risk. The reality is that both always exist regardless of what's trending.

@koeppelmann I know it's wishful thinking, but it would have been healthier if people had participated in the maker community calls and forum where the problem was already being considered rationally and the solution (dark fix) was being discussed - rather than panic on twitter.

@koeppelmann SCD was maximally inefficient (since no DSR), meaning it could not throttle adoption any further without breaking the peg. MCD is a lot more safe than SCD, but immediately after launch I can understand the dev team recommendation to still assume the worst.

Maker governance: *Carefully balances technical risk vs cryptoeconomic risk and doesn't get hacked or exploited*

Twitter mob: *Pitchforks*

Faith in humanity: *Drained by a flash loan*

At least it provides a great opportunity for the many participants I met that are working on the sidelines to promote and advance projects, ideas and companies that could actually meaningfully impact the current broken paradigm
But the billionaire hypocrisy hangs thick in the air. The view that its really just the elite having a big party at a ski resort that is justified with buzzwords and slogans is essentially correct.

Davos is a unique experience. I can see why many people have a love/hate relationship with the event; I was able to make important connections and evangelize DeFi and Blockchain to some of the worlds top investors and decision makers that would have been impossible anywhere else

@aklamun It is by design that MKR can trigger Emergency Shutdown (to defend against gov attacks even if all Emergency Oracles are compromised). Game theory is that if an ES is triggered maliciously, then the attackers MKR will not be included in the redeployment. https://t.co/JLi5Biyd59
RT @AlexanderFisher: It's a BIG DAY for the most complex production #blockchain based application in history. In a few hours, a vote for MK‚Ä¶

@aklamun This is mitigated through the Governance Security Module, which imposes a delay on governance actions, allowing an emergency shutdown and redeployment process to be triggered in response to an attempted attack. I'm surprised the author mentions the OSM, while ignoring the GSM

@Rewkang @cyounessi1 @richatmakerdao @cburniske @compoundfinance I would disagree, as I think people use stablecoins mainly because they are risk averse - and getting some risk-free money on top of your stable store of value is a pretty good deal. But of course it is impossible to predict market behavior. We can only wait and see.

@Rewkang @cyounessi1 @richatmakerdao @cburniske @compoundfinance DSR will actually also boost compound rates, so drive more users that way. But more importantly it enables passive income for users that are in Dai because they are risk averse and thus won‚Äôt use compound.

@Rewkang @cyounessi1 @richatmakerdao @cburniske @compoundfinance DSR results in lower SF because it increases demand for Dai, so it means a higher supply can be supported without breaking the peg, which results in a lower SF.

@Rewkang @cyounessi1 @richatmakerdao @cburniske @compoundfinance Compound has lower LR and LP, which probably plays a big role why users won‚Äôt switch even though SF is lower. That won‚Äôt be true for MCD migration. However a lot of users will probably not pay attention at all and thus won‚Äôt migrate - this is probably also happening with compound

@Rewkang @cyounessi1 @richatmakerdao @cburniske CDP holders will want to upgrade because: 1) lower SF in MCD because of DSR 2) the SF cost of migration can be instantly recouped by immediately drawing more Dai, so there is no downside to migrating

@gakonst @ricburton If the ecosystem is fully prepared for an ES/redeployment cycle, then the CDP user experience would be a simple one-click upgrade.\n\nIt will still take years for the ecosystem to get fully prepared, but even without preparation an emergency shutdown will keep user funds safe.

@gakonst @ricburton Oracle security delay -> Emergency shutdown -> redeployment = Oracle problem solved\n\nGetting the DeFi ecosystem upgraded to handle graceful redeployments will be a challenge, but it's not an unsolvable task.

However: there is going to be higher rates for borrowing with an asset that is actively staking, since that has higher risk.

@jperkinsx @Davidutro @SetProtocol @MakerDAO Yes pls. A token/smart contract that always buys Dai for USDC at the price of 0.999 Dai/USDC, and sells Dai for USDC at the price of 1.001 Dai/USDC as long as any reserves are available. Suppliers deposit equivalent amount of Dai/USDC on each side.

@puntium @compoundfinance @MakerDAO @dydxprotocol The 125% Liquidation Ratio on Compound vs 150% on Maker likely has an impact. Meaning that borrowers are unwilling to refinance even if they get lower rates, because they can get more leverage on Compound.

So excited for #Devcon! MakerDAO will have some big news, and the Maker Foundation will have 6! speakers at the event! https://t.co/tiNFSAYqGs
@AaronFosterReal @ChrisBlec That will be another potential one of many future synthetic asset alongside other choices such as EuroDai and YuanDai.
@LeoMorozovskii @alexgausman @TrustlessState @ameensol Unfortunately none such assets exist yet :(

@rob_mose Yes, and this is actually built in to how collateral in MCD functions (you have the freedom to increase your collateralization in order to reduce your stability fee). But the end result is still to manage the total supply and prevent unsustainable bubbles.

@rob_mose @ameensol @TrustlessState @alexgausman So you have to limit your exposure to ETH so that you don't push its market cap beyond what its fundamentals can carry. This is done by increasing the stability fee for CDPs, which in turn increases Dai price, and the DSR then goes down to mitigate the increased Dai price.

@rob_mose @ameensol @TrustlessState @alexgausman The problem is then if Dai demand for this Dai starts falling, and the Dai supply shrinks to 50 billion. Then you've suddenly got the collateral that used to back 50 billion Dai dumped on the market. This then triggers liquidations, and the economy would enter a death spiral.

@rob_mose @ameensol @TrustlessState @alexgausman Lets say the natural market cap of ETH is 100 billion. Theoretically you could issue 100 billion Dai from that, and through the use of ETH as collateral pump the ETH price to 500 billion or w/e - some unsustainable number not in line with fundamentals.

@rob_mose However, there is a cost: The more restrictive the collateral for a particular synthetic asset is, the lower the savings rate such an asset would have, since it would not be able to safely support a very large supply.

@rob_mose Purity assets allow users to select what kind of assets their stablecoin is backed by. And this can be done *without* introducing black swan risk to the asset because they will still be protected by MKR in the same way as any other synthetic asset

Thanks @rob_mose for this great idea: If there is enough demand for it, MakerDAO governance can use it's capability to issue synthetic assets, to also issue an ETH-purity stablecoin. I'd never considered this possibility before, but it is actually a very interesting frontier.

@ameensol @RyanSAdams Someone else suggested this: What if, post-MCD, using the synthetic asset capability of MakerDAO, MKR holders issued their own ETH-only USD-Dai. Of course this would have to be properly risk managed, because it would share its MKR backstop with the other Dai stablecoins.

@rob_mose @ameensol @TrustlessState @alexgausman Yes, that's a good idea. However I still believe such an asset, if it became popular, could only be kept safe if it had high negative interest rates. If it became too big and became a driver of the ETH price, we'd enter death spiral territory.

@ameensol @RyanSAdams You can do that, but it would have no effect on the actual practical value users would end up with since everyone getting their hands on liquid ETH in a crash would just further exacerbate that crash. Believe me, this is the exact scenario I've spent 5 years trying to solve.

@LeoMorozovskii @alexgausman @TrustlessState @ameensol The assets on top of Ethereum (that are there because of the finality guarantees) would always drive fees to stakers, regardless of the market price. (And no, this still doesn't mean ETH-only-Dai can survive an ETH exchange crackdown)
@TrustlessState @ameensol @alexgausman Don't you think that transaction finality transcends this issue though?
@ameensol @TrustlessState @alexgausman The greatest form of flattery!

@LeoMorozovskii @alexgausman @TrustlessState @ameensol That's not how PoS works. Finality means that even at very low market cap, Ethereum can still secure infinite value. This is a great thing btw, not a bad thing, because it ensures Ethereum will have tons of transactions driving fees to ETH stakers and holders forever.

@DanielRWitte @ameensol @TrustlessState @alexgausman Instead of thinking about trust, think of it as risk. MKR is in the business of managing that risk. That is the raison d'etre of the asset. MKR holders put their money on the line and accept the beating for their own bad decisions so that Dai holders can sleep safely.

@ameensol @TrustlessState @alexgausman Just carelessly adding a bunch of stocks regulated by the same government would be a big disaster. It needs to be a extremely careful and thoughtful approach "dipping our toes". Diversification would be key throughout. Low debt ceiling is your friend.
@TrustlessState @ameensol @alexgausman I'm worried about every single hypothetical risk. And there's only way to mitigate that worry: diversification.

@TrustlessState @alexgausman @ameensol @MakerDAO I think getting the started on the skillset and know-how to safely scale Dai in the future is critical. So I would prefer a cautious "dip our toes" approach, which seems to be the general consensus in Maker governance so far.

@ameensol @TrustlessState @alexgausman Absolutely I completely get that. But now we're back to: What happens to the ETH price if the ETH exchanges are shut down in the same hypothetical manner real world collateral would be shut down? Especially factoring in massive ETH-backed Dai debt?
@AaronFosterReal @ChrisBlec Dai is pegged to fiat, so being exchangeable for it is the most critical test of its core functionality.

@TrustlessState @alexgausman @ameensol The choice of Dai holders to pick which deployment they want to use is the foundation of MakerDAO governance. But it would incredibly dangerous to have a credit fuelled bubble in ETH caused by unsafe risk parameters due to ETH maximalism.
@ameensol @RyanSAdams But to be clear: the MCD code base is completely open source.
@joselfgaray Market value of crypto is decided by the off ramps.

@ameensol @RyanSAdams Why not just use ETH? A stablecoin backed by a single asset is not sustainable in the long run as it will either need massive negative interest rates to discourage use, or will be susceptible to a black swan event from a death spiral. Using native ETH as money would be safer.

@AaronFosterReal @ChrisBlec What's an example of a trustless bitcoin or ethereum exchange that has real liquidity against real world value? A DEX using Dai unfortunately doesn't count, because Dai relies on ETH in the first place.
@joselfgaray Dai doesn't care about core value. It cares about market price.
@Rewkang Agreed, that's why you diversify across many different jurisdictions, so the loss inflicted by any particular government can easily be absorbed.

@kaiynne What if we did a rational assessment of the risk that said guys with guns would do something crazy on a per country basis, and then managed our exposure accordingly with most of our value held in the most sane jurisdictions?
@epheph If all exchanges and OTC desks are shut down, where does this gradual price discovery happen? Who will buy the cascade of CDP liquidations if they have no place to offload it?
@kaiynne Shouldn't we bake it out of that framework then?
@joselfgaray The philosophical implications are irrelevant for Dai. You can't prop a stablecoin up with ideology. What matters is the impact on price.

@DegenSpartan There is an easy solution to the oracle problems, and it's coming in MCD: The oracle security delay and emergency shutdown guarantees oracle attacks will not cause loss of funds for Dai users. The problem is the actual impact on collateral value in case of a crackdown.

@hasufl @panekkkk @Mariandipietra @zhusu In short: Dai supply follows CDP demand. CDP demand follows stability fee. Stability fee follows Dai demand. Ergo, Dai supply follows Dai demand. Initially it's a manual process that can be increasingly automated over time.

@hasufl @panekkkk @Mariandipietra @zhusu To get a better idea of how the Dai price is stabilized, here are some links: https://t.co/JCYjUiiwZr https://t.co/v7BwAZVspZ - The current process in SCD is very simple and crude, but will be significantly improved in MCD. Btw, this is also how central banks stabilize currency

@jangrabski @udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra That's a cool idea, but I believe the chainlink/augur model of having tokens directly stake on what data they think is honest, and getting paid and have their data weighted based on how much they stake, would work similar to what you're suggesting, but a bit more robust.

@udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra Diversification is another key pillar of a solid decentralized oracle. So a hypothetical scenario is that something like Chainlink was voted in to the Decentralized oracle with a weighting of e.g. 5. Over time decentralization will be pushed to the point of diminishing returns.

@udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra After Multi Collateral Dai launch, modifying the sources and weighting of the decentralized oracle will be a part of the quarterly governance process. Track record is a strong data point to rely on, so it's likely that the current oracles will remain, at least for a while.

@udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra In the long run it is obviously the MKR governance community that needs to decide what "decentralized" and "secure" means, using scientific governance to carefully select and review what sources go into the decentralized oracle and their weighting.

@udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra Second, the fact that the current decentralized oracle is highly distributed and highly secure is ultimately just a claim made by the Foundation. In the short run trusting this claim isn't much different from trusting there are no backdoors in the code.

@udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra The system can then be redeployed instantly after an attack, with the bad oracles removed. "Troll shutdowns" results in the MKR of the trolls being removed in the MKR distribution of the redeployment. Wallets/exchanges can transition from one deployment to another seamlessly.

@udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra Two mechanisms enable this: a 1 hour security delay on the input of the oracles, and the Emergency Shutdown - the ability for a low quorum of MKR voters to instantly stop and perform a graceful settlement of the system, reimbursing all users the collateral they are entitled to.

@udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra First, the system will not rely on the decentralized oracle being honest, on the contrary it is designed assuming the oracle will attack the system at any moment, and can survive such an attack with near-zero risk and minimal costs compared to those of the attacker.

@udiWertheimer @nanexcool @Mariandipietra To directly address your meta point: the current decentralized oracle solution for the Single Collateral Dai beta is robust enough for scaling to a couple of hundred million dollars. But it still isn't trustless, and it will see some major upgrades in Multi Collateral Dai.
